H0.text: Mitochondria is the structure whose fluid‑filled interior, called the matrix, contains most of the cell’s ATP.

H1.text: The nucleus is the structure whose fluid‑filled interior is called the matrix, where most of the cell’s ATP is produced.

H2.text: Golgi apparatus is the structure whose fluid-filled interior is called matrix, where most of the cell’s ATP is made.

H3.text: Enzyme is the term for the fluid-filled interior of a structure where most of the cell’s ATP is made.

A4.text: The matrix is important in the production of ATP with the aid of the ATP synthase contained in the inner membrane.

A5.text: The matrix contains a highly concentrated mixture of hundreds of enzymes, special mitochondrial ribosomes, tRNA, and several copies of the mitochondrial DNA genome.
